default-command.title: default-command
default-command.description: The restic or resticprofile command to use when no command was specified

group-continue-on-error.title: group-continue-on-error
group-continue-on-error.description: Enable groups to continue with the next profile(s) instead of stopping at the first failure

ionice.title: ionice
ionice.description: Enables setting the unix IO priority class and level for resticprofile and child processes (only on unix OS).

ionice-class.title: ionice-class
ionice-class.description: Sets the unix "ionice-class" to apply when "ionice" is enabled

ionice-level.title: ionice-level
ionice-level.description: Sets the unix "ionice-level" to apply when "ionice" is enabled

legacy-arguments.title: legacy-arguments
legacy-arguments.description: Legacy, broken arguments mode of resticprofile before version 0.15 [deprecated]

min-memory.title: min-memory
min-memory.description: Minimum available memory (in MB) required to run any commands - see https://creativeprojects.github.io/resticprofile/usage/memory/

nice.title: nice
nice.description: Sets the unix "nice" value for resticprofile and child processes (on any OS)

prevent-sleep.title: prevent-sleep
prevent-sleep.description: Prevent the system from sleeping while running commands - see https://creativeprojects.github.io/resticprofile/configuration/sleep/

priority.title: priority
priority.description: Sets process priority class for resticprofile and child processes (on any OS)

restic-arguments-filter.title: restic-arguments-filter
restic-arguments-filter.description: Remove unknown flags instead of passing all configured flags to restic

restic-binary.title: restic-binary
restic-binary.description: Full path of the restic executable (detected if not set)

scheduler.title: scheduler
scheduler.description: Leave blank for the default scheduler or use "crond" to select cron on supported operating systems

systemd-timer-template.title: systemd-timer-template
systemd-timer-template.description: File containing the go template to generate a systemd timer - see https://creativeprojects.github.io/resticprofile/schedules/systemd/

systemd-unit-template.title: systemd-unit-template
systemd-unit-template.description: File containing the go template to generate a systemd unit - see https://creativeprojects.github.io/resticprofile/schedules/systemd/

continue-on-error.title: continue-on-error
continue-on-error.description: Continue with the next profile on a failure, overrides "global.group-continue-on-error"

backup.title: backup
backup.description:
The "backup" command creates a new snapshot and saves the files and directories
given as the arguments.

cache-dir.title: cache-dir
cache-dir.description: set the cache directory&. (default: use system default cache directory)

check-after.title: check-after
check-after.description: Check the repository after the backup command succeeded

check-before.title: check-before
check-before.description: Check the repository before starting the backup command

exclude-caches.title: exclude-caches
exclude-caches.description: excludes cache directories that are marked with a CACHEDIR.TAG file. See https://bford.info/cachedir/ for the Cache Directory Tagging Standard

extended-status.title: extended-status
extended-status.description: set output mode to JSON for commands that support it

force.title: force
force.description: force re-reading the target files/directories (overrides the "parent" flag)

key-hint.title: key-hint
key-hint.description: key ID of key to try decrypting first (default: $RESTIC_KEY_HINT)

limit-download.title: limit-download
limit-download.description: limits downloads to a maximum rate in KiB/s. (default: unlimited)

limit-upload.title: limit-upload
limit-upload.description: limits uploads to a maximum rate in KiB/s. (default: unlimited)

no-cache.title: no-cache
no-cache.description: do not use a local cache

no-error-on-warning.title: no-error-on-warning
no-error-on-warning.description: Do not fail the backup when some files could not be read

no-lock.title: no-lock
no-lock.description: do not lock the repository, this allows some operations on read-only repositories

one-file-system.title: one-file-system
one-file-system.description: exclude other file systems, don't cross filesystem boundaries and subvolumes

parent.title: parent
parent.description: use this parent snapshot (default: latest snapshot in the group determined by --group-by and not newer than the timestamp determined by --time)

password-command.title: password-command
password-command.description: shell command to obtain the repository password from (default: $RESTIC_PASSWORD_COMMAND)

password-file.title: password-file
password-file.description: file to read the repository password from (default: $RESTIC_PASSWORD_FILE)

quiet.title: quiet
quiet.description: do not output comprehensive progress report

repo.title: repo
repo.description: repository to backup to or restore from (default: $RESTIC_REPOSITORY)

schedule-lock-mode.title: schedule-lock-mode
schedule-lock-mode.description: Specify how locks are used when running on schedule - see https://creativeprojects.github.io/resticprofile/schedules/configuration/

schedule-log.title: schedule-log
schedule-log.description: Redirect the output into a log file or to syslog when running on schedule

schedule-permission.title: schedule-permission
schedule-permission.description: Specify whether the schedule runs with system or user privileges - see https://creativeprojects.github.io/resticprofile/schedules/configuration/

schedule-priority.title: schedule-priority
schedule-priority.description: Set the priority at which the schedule is run

source-base.title: source-base
source-base.description: The base path to resolve relative backup paths against. Defaults to current directory if unset or empty (see also "base-dir" in profile)

stdin-filename.title: stdin-filename
stdin-filename.description: filename to use when reading from stdin

tls-client-cert.title: tls-client-cert
tls-client-cert.description: path to a file containing PEM encoded TLS client certificate and private key (default: $RESTIC_TLS_CLIENT_CERT)

with-atime.title: with-atime
with-atime.description: store the atime for all files and directories

base-dir.title: base-dir
base-dir.description: Sets the working directory for this profile. The profile will fail when the working directory cannot be changed. Leave empty to use the current directory instead

cacert.title: cacert
cacert.description: file to load root certificates from (default: use system certificates or $RESTIC_CACERT)

cache.description: The "cache" command allows listing and cleaning local cache directories.

cache-dir.description: set the cache directory&. (default: use system default cache directory)

limit-upload.description: limits uploads to a maximum rate in KiB/s. (default: unlimited)

check.title: check
check.description:
The "check" command tests the repository for errors and reports any errors it
finds. It can also be used to read all data and therefore simulate a restore.

By default, the "check" command will always load all data directly from the
repository and not use a local cache.

read-data-subset.description: read a subset of data packs, specified as 'n/t' for specific part, or either 'x%' or 'x.y%' or a size in bytes with suffixes k/K, m/M, g/G, t/T for a random subset

with-cache.title: with-cache
with-cache.description: use existing cache, only read uncached data from repository

diff.title: diff
diff.description:
The "diff" command shows differences from the first to the second snapshot. The
first characters in each line display what has happened to a particular file or
directory:

+  The item was added
-  The item was removed
U  The metadata (access mode, timestamps, ...) for the item was updated
M  The file's content was modified
T  The type was changed, e.g. a file was made a symlink

dump.title: dump
dump.description:
The "dump" command extracts files from a snapshot from the repository. If a
single file is selected, it prints its contents to stdout. Folders are output
as a tar (default) or zip file containing the contents of the specified folder.
Pass "/" as file name to dump the whole snapshot as an archive file.

The special snapshot "latest" can be used to use the latest snapshot in the
repository.

force-inactive-lock.description: Allows to lock when the existing lock is considered stale

forget.title: forget
forget.description:
The "forget" command removes snapshots according to a policy. All snapshots are
first divided into groups according to "--group-by", and after that the policy
specified by the "--keep-*" options is applied to each group individually.

Please note that this command really only deletes the snapshot object in the
repository, which is a reference to data stored there. In order to remove the
unreferenced data after "forget" was run successfully, see the "prune" command.

Please also read the documentation for "forget" to learn about some important
security considerations.

ls.title: ls
ls.description:
The "ls" command lists files and directories in a snapshot.

The special snapshot ID "latest" can be used to list files and
directories of the latest snapshot in the repository. The
--host flag can be used in conjunction to select the latest
snapshot originating from a certain host only.

File listings can optionally be filtered by directories. Any
positional arguments after the snapshot ID are interpreted as
absolute directory paths, and only files inside those directories
will be listed. If the --recursive flag is used, then the filter
will allow traversing into matching directories' subfolders.
Any directory paths specified must be absolute (starting with
a path separator); paths use the forward slash '/' as separator.

mount.title: mount
mount.description:
The "mount" command mounts the repository via fuse to a directory. This is a
read-only mount.


If you need a different template for directories that contain snapshots,
you can pass a time template via --time-template and path templates via
--path-template.

Example time template without colons:


--time-template "2006-01-02_15-04-05"


You need to specify a sample format for exactly the following timestamp:


Mon Jan 2 15:04:05 -0700 MST 2006


For details please see the documentation for time.Format() at:
  https://godoc.org/time#Time.Format

For path templates, you can use the following patterns which will be replaced:
    %i by short snapshot ID
    %I by long snapshot ID
    %u by username
    %h by hostname
    %t by tags
    %T by timestamp as specified by --time-template

The default path templates are:
    "ids/%i"
    "snapshots/%T"
    "hosts/%h/%T"
    "tags/%t/%T"

allow-other.title: allow-other
allow-other.description: allow other users to access the data in the mounted directory

allow-root.description: allow root user to access the data in the mounted directory [deprecated, removed in 0.10.0]

recover.title: recover
recover.description:
The "recover" command builds a new snapshot from all directories it can find in
the raw data of the repository which are not referenced in an existing snapshot.
It can be used if, for example, a snapshot has been removed by accident with "forget".

restore.title: restore
restore.description:
The "restore" command extracts the data from a snapshot from the repository to
a directory.

The special snapshot "latest" can be used to restore the latest snapshot in the
repository.

retention.title: retention
retention.description:
The "forget" command removes snapshots according to a policy. All snapshots are
first divided into groups according to "--group-by", and after that the policy
specified by the "--keep-*" options is applied to each group individually.

Please note that this command really only deletes the snapshot object in the
repository, which is a reference to data stored there. In order to remove the
unreferenced data after "forget" was run successfully, see the "prune" command.

Please also read the documentation for "forget" to learn about some important
security considerations.

after-backup.title: after-backup
after-backup.description: Apply retention after the backup command succeeded. Defaults to true if any "keep-*" flag is set and "before-backup" is unset

before-backup.title: before-backup
before-backup.description: Apply retention before starting the backup command

cache-dir.title: cache-dir
cache-dir.description: set the cache directory&. (default: use system default cache directory)

dry-run.title: dry-run
dry-run.description: do not delete anything, just print what would be done

extended-status.title: extended-status
extended-status.description: set output mode to JSON for commands that support it

group-by.title: group-by
group-by.description: group snapshots by host, paths and/or tags, separated by comma (disable grouping with '')

keep-daily.title: keep-daily
keep-daily.description: keep the last n daily snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all daily snapshots)

keep-hourly.title: keep-hourly
keep-hourly.description: keep the last n hourly snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all hourly snapshots)

keep-last.title: keep-last
keep-last.description: keep the last n snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all snapshots)

keep-monthly.title: keep-monthly
keep-monthly.description: keep the last n monthly snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all monthly snapshots)

keep-weekly.title: keep-weekly
keep-weekly.description: keep the last n weekly snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all weekly snapshots)

keep-within.title: keep-within
keep-within.description: keep snapshots that are newer than duration (eg. 1y5m7d2h) relative to the latest snapshot

keep-yearly.title: keep-yearly
keep-yearly.description: keep the last n yearly snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all yearly snapshots)

key-hint.description: key ID of key to try decrypting first (default: $RESTIC_KEY_HINT)

stats.title: stats
stats.description:
The "stats" command walks one or multiple snapshots in a repository
and accumulates statistics about the data stored therein. It reports
on the number of unique files and their sizes, according to one of
the counting modes as given by the --mode flag.

It operates on all snapshots matching the selection criteria or all
snapshots if nothing is specified. The special snapshot ID "latest"
is also supported. Some modes make more sense over
just a single snapshot, while others are useful across all snapshots,
depending on what you are trying to calculate.

The modes are:

restore-size: (default) Counts the size of the restored files.
files-by-contents: Counts total size of files, where a file is
considered unique if it has unique contents.
raw-data: Counts the size of blobs in the repository, regardless of
how many files reference them.
blobs-per-file: A combination of files-by-contents and raw-data.


Refer to the online manual for more details about each mode.

tag.title: tag
tag.description:
The "tag" command allows you to modify tags on exiting snapshots.

You can either set/replace the entire set of tags on a snapshot, or
add tags to/remove tags from the existing set.

When no snapshot-ID is given, all snapshots matching the host, tag and path filter criteria are modified.
